every.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: used to refer to all the people or things in a particular group or all the parts of something
every.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: We looked carefully at every car that drove past.
Every child will receive a certificate at the end of the course.
I enjoyed every minute of the film.
I listened carefully to every word he said.
He seems to know every single person in the school.
They made us pick up every last scrap of paper.
every.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: used to say how often something happens
every.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Freda had to stop to rest every hundred metres or so  (=each time she had gone 100 metres).
They see each other every day.
Richard visits his mother every week.
Re-apply your sunscreen every two hours.
every.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: used to say how much distance there is between the things in a line
every.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: There were traffic lights every ten yards.
every.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: We wish you every happiness in your new home.
There is every chance that he will recover.
We have every reason to believe that the operation will be a success.
We have every intention of winning this competition.
every.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with every
every.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0: You use every with a singular noun and a singular verb
Every person has the right to a fair trial
every.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1: Don’t use every with a plural noun
every.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2: You usually use ‘his’, ‘her’, ‘himself’, or ‘herself’ after every
Every woman can speak for herself
every.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3: However, you can use ‘their’, ‘they’, ‘them’ etc when you do not want to say whether the people are male or female
Every child has their own room
